questions.text: A patient underwent mastectomy, and a drain was inserted beneath the flap. What type of drain is it?
questions.solution:
Drains are placed at wounds or surgical sites to accumulate/drain any free gas, pus etc which would render the surgical site an infection free environment and enhance the healing process.

There are different types of surgical drains which are as follows:

  • Open drains: works on the principle of gravity includes rubber tube or plastic sheets which would drain in gauze pad or stoma bag, increased risk of infection e.g. Penrose drain, corrugated rubber drain
  • Closed drains: works on the principle of suction, includes tubes attached to bag or bottle e.g. Jackson-pratt drain, romovac suction drain
  • Semi closed drain: works on the principle of of capillary effect, eg: ICD tubes

Removal of drain: the POD is important

  1. For bleeding (thyroidectomy) - 24hrs later removed
  2. For serous collections (mastectomy) - 5days
  3. Colorectal surgery (anastomotic leakage) - 5-7 days
  4. CBD drain-T tube - minimum 10 days its must be retained

The only place in alimentary tract surgery where it is still routinely advocated is for esophageal surgery

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557687/

questions.text:
A midline neck swelling moves with deglutition. Patient has tachycardia and exophthalmos. What are the investigation to be done:
1. Thyroid scan
2. FNAC
3. Thyroid function test
4. PET scan
5. Thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Based on the above case scenario, it can be a case of GRAVES disease or nodular goitre with toxicosis

Thyroid scan: 2 RAIU (radio active iodine uptake) study used

  1. I123: half life of 12 hr, used for diagnostic purpose
  2. I131: half life of 8 days, used for therapeutic purpose, emits beta rays which helps in ablation of the gland

Fine-needle aspiration cytology

As this is toxicosis cases, FNAC is less yielding, most of the time the aspirate contains blood, but this can be considered if it is a nodular goitre

Thyroid function test

Serum TSH and thyroid hormone levels should be measured. If hyperthyroidism associated with a discrete swelling is confirmed biochemically, it indicates either a 'toxic adenoma' or a manifestation of toxic multinodular goitre.

Autoantibody titres

Long acting thyroid stimulation (LATS) antibody is elevated in GRAVES disease

PETCT

Is of no use in thyroid cancer as investigation of choice for detection of metastasis in thyroid cancer is THYROID SCAN

When serum thyroglobulin (tumor marker for thyroid cancer) is elevated but I123 thyroid scan is normal, in this condition only PETCT is useful in detecting metastasis.

choices.text: For confirming the diagnosis of malignancy

questions.text: Surgery is done in carcinoma breast, frozen section was done. This procedure will be useful for all expect
questions.solution:
Frozen section done during the evaluation and surgery of breast carcinoma is not useful for definitive diagnosis. Subcapsular micrometasis are usually missed on frozen sections.

Frozen sections are usually used whilst doing breast conserving surgeries for the assessment of tumor margins and for detecting metastasis also.

It is also used during sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) and axillary lymph node biopsy (ALNB) assessment and of nodal metastasis.

To confirm the diagnosis of malignancy is not an indication because we could have already diagnosed the cancer by TRU CUT biopsy.

questions.text: A 75 years old male patient presented with hematuria, urine microscopic examination reveals- transitional cell cancer. CT scan shows 2*2cm mass in bladder. What is the management
questions.solution:
• Non invasive muscle tumor (stage Ta, T1): TURBT + intravescial BCG therapy
  • Muscle invasive bladder tumor (stage> T2): radical cystectomy + illeal conduit

Investigations:

Cystourethroscopy

Flexible cystourethroscopy under local anaesthetic is the mainstay of diagnosis and should always be performed on patients with haematuria.

CT urogram is the gold standard evaluation for upper tract disease.

MRI of the bladder can be useful in staging of the primary tumour. Imaging should ideally be performed prior to transurethral resection of the bladder tumour (TURBT) as false-positive T3 disease can be diagnosed if cross-sectional imaging is carried out too soon after TURBT

Treatment:

Transurethral resection(TURBT)

The initial management of bladder tumours consists of TURBT for accurate staging purposes. This is performed with a rigid cystoscopy under general anaesthesia.

choices.text: Tip of the nose to ear lobule to between xiphoid process and umbilicus
Tip of the nose to ear lobule to between manubrium and umbilicus
Angle of mouth to ear lobe to xiphisternum
Angle of mouth to umbilicus and pubic symphysis

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct method for measurement of an NG tube?
questions.solution:
Selecting the length to be inserted in an adult and children:

  • NEX method (in adults): nose → ear lobule → xiphisternum
  • NEMU (preferred in children): nose → ear lobe → midpoint between xiphoid process and umbilicus

Ryle's tube coiling in mouth: tracheo-esophageal atresia (TEF)

Ryle's tube in chest: diaphragmatic hernia

Best method to confirm the position of tip of ryle's tube:

  • Aspiration and Ph testing using litmus paper

questions.text: A patient presented with jaundice to hospital, USG and CECT was done shows no stone in gall bladder but intrahepatic biliary radicle are dilated. What is the next investigation done?
questions.solution:
MRCP - is a T2 weighted MRI with bile acting itself as contrast, it is the investigation of choice for bile duct pathology

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive modality that provides excellent images of the gallbladder and biliary system

without the potential complications of the ERCP and PTC, they can demonstrate ductal abnormalities, including obstruction/stricture, stones and tumours.

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography, projectional images demonstrating stones and hilar obstruction.

ERCP: is an invasive procedure, hence it is used for diagnostic purpose (eg: ERCP sphincterotomy), a side viewing endoscope is used as show in the image below. The most common complication of this procedure is acute pancreatitis

PERCUTANEOUS TRANSHEPATIC CHOLANGIOGRAPHY

Investigation of choice to study the proximal bile duct (MRCP mainly used to visualise the distal CBD)

questions.text: With cannula shown below, what is the flow rate/minute?
questions.solution:
The give image is of green colored IV cannula

Specifications of this cannula: 18 gauge, external diameter of 1.3mm, length of : 32\45mm with a flow rate of 90ml/min, most commonly used in trauma and quick blood transfusions

  • In trauma: minimum 2 green cannula is used
  • Cannulas used when maximum and faster infusion required: orange (14G) and grey (16G) cannulas.
  • Fluid infused: crystalloids (normal saline) of 1litre given immediately

Reference: https://www.neotecmedical.com/safety-i-v-cannula-with-injection-v.

questions.text:
A patient who had Mc Burney's incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision. What are the structures cut?
1. External oblique
2. Internal oblique
3. Transverse abdominis
4. Rectus abdominis
questions.solution:
• When the preoperative diagnosis is considered reasonably certain, the incision that is widely used for appendicectomy is the so-called gridiron incision or Mc Burneys incision
  • The gridiron incision is made at right angles to a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, its centre being along the line at McBurney's point (medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd), then it will be extended to the external oblique aponeurosis, no muscle is cut, after opening the external oblique aponeurosis, we will do splitting of internal oblique/transversus abdominis using artery forceps.
  • So Mc Burneys/grid iron incision is called muscle splitting incision

Gridiron incision for appendicitis, at right angles to a line joining the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus, centred on McBurney's point

  • If better access is required or when appendix is located retrocecal or paracecal, it is possible to convert the gridiron to a Rutherford Morison by cutting the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles laterally in the line of the incision, external oblique muscle can also be cut.
  • Rectus abdominis muscle is never cut
  • In recent years transverse skin crease (Lanz) incision has become more popular, as the exposure is better and extension, when needed, is easier.
  • The incision, appropriate in length to the size and obesity of the patient, is made approximately 2 cm below the umbilicus centred on the midclavicular-mid inguinal

Transverse or skin crease (Lanz) incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular-mid inguinal line

questions.text: A patient had chest trauma, had normal respiratory rate and respiratory effort. Which of the following must not be done?
questions.solution:
The given plain x-ray shows elevation of the left side of the diaphragm with abdominal contents displaced suggestive of diaphragmatic hernia following a blunt trauma due to RTA.

Blunt trauma causes a huge tear in diaphragm, than a penetrating trauma because compressive forces applied to pelvis and abdomen drain blunt trauma

BERGVIST TRIAD;

  1. Fracture of ribs
  2. Fracture of spine
  3. Diaphragmatic injury

Presentation in blunt trauma diaphragmatic hernia is late

CXR can diagnose this condition

Gold standard: diagnostic laparoscopy or VATS (video assisted thoracic surgery)

In this condition chest tube (ICD) insertion is contraindicated as it can worsen the given clinical picture.

Chest tube insertion is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, pleural effusion etc.

Treatment:

Diaphragmatic hernia should be managed by abdominal approach by a proline suture, as visceral injuries can also be treated along the way.

Log roll is contraindicated in pelvic fracture

questions.text: What is the most common complication on inserting a central vein below this bone?
questions.solution:
Complications of central venous catheter insertion

  • Failure to place the catheter (22%)
  • Arterial puncture (5%)
  • Malposition of catheter (4%)
  • Pneumothorax (1%)
  • Subcutaneous hematoma (1%)
  • Hemothorax (1%)
  • Cardiac arrest (<1%)

If arterial puncture occurs of subclavian artery:

  • Immediate removal of catheter with pressure can result in uncontrolled hemorrhage and AV fistula
  • Prolonged arterial stroke catheterisation can result in thrombosis and neurological deficits and stroke
  • Recent studies says - leaving the catheter in place and prompt repair carries less morbidity and mortality than giving pressure
  • Left sided IJV or subclavian access carries a high risk of lymphatic injury due to a atomic location of thoracic duct, but lymphatics injury can happen in right side also

Central vein catheter related sepsis: 2 approaches

  1. Swab from the central vein using endoluminal brush for culture sensitivity and blood culture sensitivity, if the organism isolated are same in both specimen-remove the catheter and start on culture sensitive antibiotics
  2. Aspirate blood from central vein and peripheral vein and send for culture sensitivity, if Same organism isolated-remove the catheter,

Reference: IJCIIS July 2015, Craik kombau

choices.text: Segmental resection of the vessel with replacement by reverse saphenous vein graft

questions.text: 20 years old male met with road traffic accident and suffered with upper limb injury with laceration over arm. Radial and ulnar pulse not felt. He had longitudinal tear in brachial artery of 2.5 cm length. Ideal repair is
questions.solution:
Upper limb vascular injuries:

  • The brachial artery is best exposed through a longitudinal incision along the medial aspect of the upper arm over the groove between the triceps and biceps muscles.
  • Proximal brachial artery injuries may require control of the infraclavicular axillary artery.
  • Balloon catheter thrombectomy and flushing with heparinized saline followed by debridement of damaged arterial wall are essential to successful repair. Lacerated veins should be ligated.
  • However, if there is extensive soft tissue injury and collateral venous flow is compromised, the vein should be repaired. In repairing both venous and arterial injuries, the vein should be repaired first.
  • If the duration of arterial occlusion and ischemia is a concern, temporary intraluminal shunts may be placed in the artery.
  • Primary arterial repair of undamaged ends of vessel (end-to-end anastomosis) should be performed only if the repair is tension free.
  • Saphenous vein interposition should be chosen whenever vessel injury is extensive or if primary tension-free repair is not possible. PTFE needs to remain a second choice to autologous vein in the management of injuries of the brachial artery and forearm vessels.

questions.text:
True regarding HCC less than 3cm in size:
1. Increasing incidence globally
2. TACE is done for multimodal at tumor
3. Levatinib/ ipilimumab used in treatment of causes for tumor size <3.5 cm
4. NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC
questions.solution:
HCC is a malignant tumour arising from hepatocytes and is the most common primary liver cancer. There is a steadily rising global burden.

Incidence of HCC is Increasing, It ranks as the fifth most common cause of cancer in men and the seventh in women, representing a third of all cancer-related deaths.

New tumor marker for HCC-PIVKA (protein induced VITAMIN K absence)

On top of that Increasing incidence of morbid obesity along with lifestyle disorders, causes in turn increased risk for NASH and NAFLD which are major risk factors for HCC which in turn contribute to increased incidence of HCC.

  • TACE: is based on the fact that most of the tumor's blood supply is from hepatic artery
  • TACE is done by percutaneous fashion now (no laparotomy needed like before)
  • TAE: ischemic necrosis of tumor happens-response rate - 50%
  • To the bland embolization particles and ethiodol-recently chemotherapy agents are added to be delivered to the tumor
  • The TACE is done for patients with preserved liver function and asymptomatic multinodular tumors** without vascular invasion
  • This procedure is contraundicates for patients who have liver failure
  • I-131 or yttrium-90 can also be delivered to HCC by this method (TARE)

Chemptherapeutic agents used in HCC

  • Sorafenib-serine threonine kinase raf-1 and B raf and TK, VEGF receptor 1,2,3 and PDGF beta inhibitor. Used for advanced stage
  • Levatinib/iplimumab are used only for advanced and inoperable HCC and not for early cases

Milan's criteria: criteria for liver transplant for patients of HCC

  1. Single tumor <5cm
  2. 1-3 tumor masses each <3cm
  3. No extrahepatic metastasis

questions.text: All of the following are lower urinary tract symptoms except?
questions.solution:
The International Continence Society provides the internationally accepted definitions for symptoms relating to lower urinary tract function.

VOIDING SYMPTOMS:

  1. HESITANCY: when an individual has difficulty initiating micturition, resulting in a delay in the onset of voiding.
  2. POOR FLOW (unimproved by straining): the muscular effort used in order to initiate, maintain or improve the urinary stream.
  3. INTERMITTENT STREAM: when urine flow stops and starts, on one or more occasions.
  4. DRIBBLING: when involuntary loss of urine occurs immediately after the individual has finished passing urine.
  5. INCOMPLETE EMPTYING: the sensation that, at the end of micturition, bladder fullness persists.
  6. STRANGURY: a sensation of constantly needing to be void. Typically, the patient describes having to stand/sit for long periods with the sensation that micturition is imminent.

STORAGE SYMPTOMS:

  1. FREQUENCY - the patient considers that they are void too often during the day.
  2. NOCTURIA - the individual wakes at night at least once to void.
  3. URGENCY - a sudden compelling desire to pass urine that is difficult to defer.
  4. URGE INCONTINENCE - involuntary urinary leakage, often a large volume, immediately preceded by the sensation of urgency.
  5. NOCTURNAL ENURESIS - involuntary loss of urine during sleep.

INVESTIGATION OF CHOICE FOR LUTS; UROFLOWMETRY

Normal uroflowmetry:

Urine flow rate:

  • For a voiding volume of >200ml a peak flow rate of >15ml/s is normal
  • Flow rate <10ml is low

Voiding pressure:

  • Voiding pressure at <60cnm H2O is normal
  • Voiding pressure >80 cm H2O is high

questions.text: Most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in a male neonate?
questions.solution:
• The incidence of posterior urethral valves(PUV) is around 1 in 8000 live male births.
  • The valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them.
  • They typically lie just distal to the verumontanum and cause obstruction to the urethra.
  • They function as flap valves; although they are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow, urethral catheter can be passed retrogradely without any difficulty
  • Investigation of choice for PUV: micturating/voiding cystourethrogram
  • Urethroscopy is not useful as valve opens back as we flow irritant inside retrograde
  • Diagnosis can be made antenatal by USG showing bilateral hydronephrosis

Treatment:

Initial management - catheterisation to improve renal failure

Definitive treatment is by endoscopic ablation of the valves.

Long-term follow-up is required in view of the associated vesicoureteral reflux, bladder dysfunction and renal impairment.

A voiding cystourethrogram showing a dilated bladder with a dilated prostatic urethra above an obstruction at the level of the posterior urethral valves.

questions.text:
A patient presented to emergency department with abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice associated with chills and rigours. Cholangitis was suspected in the patient. Which of the following are components of reynauld's pentad?
1. Jaundice
2. Melena
3. hypotension
4. Altered mentation
5. hematemesis
6. Fever
questions.solution:
CHARCOT's TRIAD; has 10% mortality if not treated

  1. Fever
  2. Jaundice
  3. Right upper quadrant pain

REYNAULD's PENTAD: has 50% mortality if not treated

  1. Fever
  2. Jaundice
  3. Right upper quadrant pain
  4. Septic shock → hypotension
  5. Altered mentation
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by the finding of dilated bile ducts on ultrasonography, an obstructive picture of liver function tests and organisms identified from blood cultures.
  • Delay in appropriate treatment may result in multi-organ failure secondary to sepsis and broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and endoscopic or percutaneous transhepatic drainage are urgently required.
  • Biliary stone disease is a common predisposing factor although strictures, pancreatitis, pancreatic tumours and parasites may also be responsible.
  • If an obstructive cause is identifed it must be urgently treated by ERCP, sphincterotomy (± stent) or percutaneous drainage.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about colon cancer
1. Colon cancer incidence is decreased by metformin
2. Right and left colon cancers have different presentations
3. Colon cancers can be hereditary
4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver
questions.solution:
• Metformin is biguanide commonly used for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus but it also helps in reducing the risk of developing colon cancer, it deregulates cellular energy supply by inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Metformin has shown results to reduce the risk of pancreatic, breast and prostate cancer also
  • NSAID's, aspirin and metformin are drugs having protective effect for colon cancer
  • Colonic cancer can spread locally, via the lymphatics, bloodstream (haematogenous) or across the peritoneal cavity (transcoelomic spread).
  • Direct spread may be longitudinal or radial.
  • Involvement of the lymph nodes by tumour progresses from those closest to the bowel along the course of lymphatics to central nodes
  • Haematogenous spread is most commonly to the liver via the portal vein.
  • Hereditary colon cancer: HNPCC, FAP
  • Colon cancer is associated with consumption of red meat and particularly processed red meat products
  • Smoking, animal fat and alcohol have increased risk of colon cancer
  • Cholecystectomy may marginally increase the risk of right colon cancer
  • IBD is a risk factor for colon cancer
  • Left side of the colon is usually present with a change in bowel habit or rectal bleeding, obstruction
  • Right side (proximal lesions) typically present with iron deficiency anaemia, melena or a mass.

questions.text: In cases of carcinoma breast with HER-2 neu IHC. Which of the following score needs further FISH study?
questions.solution:
FISH testing is done on breast cancer tissue removed during biopsy to see if the cells have extra copies of the HER2 gene. The more copies of the HER2 gene that are present, the more HER2 receptors the cells have. These HER2 receptors receive signals that stimulate the growth of breast cancer cells.

HER 2 neu interpretation

  • 0-1+ negative, they do not respond to drugs that target these receptors.
  • 2+ equivocal, FISH is done to differentiate (this is borderline so it needs FISH to confirm)
  • 3+ positive for her2 neu they respond to drugs.

Reference: https://www.breastcancer.org/screening-testing/fish-test

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supplies which structures
1. Esophagus
2. Thyroid
3. Parathyroid
4. Thymus
questions.solution:
• The inferior thyroid artery (ITA) is considered the principal blood supplier of the thyroid gland.
  • The ITA gives rise to the ascending cervical artery, the inferior laryngeal artery, and also gives pharyngeal, tracheal, and esophageal
  • ITA also supplies the four parathyroid glands.

Blood supply of esophagus:

Cricopharyngeal muscle (inlet of esophagus) is supplied by superior thyroid artery

  1. Cervical esophagus: predominantly by inferior thyroid artery
  2. Thoracic esophagus: aorta, both right and left bronchial artery, along with descending branch from inferior thyroid artery, intercostal artery and ascending branch from inferior phrenic artery
  3. Abdominal esophagus: left gastric artery and inferior phrenic artery

Blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic artery.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with abdominal pain and obstipation for 3 days. He gives a history of bull gore injury to the abdomen 3 days back. His X-ray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• The given X ray of Gas under the diaphragm with characteristic history of bull gore to the abdomen is suggestive of hollow viscus perforation with clinical findings such as abdominal pain and obstipation emphasising the diagnosis.
  • Best X-RAY for perforation: X-RAY abdomen erect-rigger sign, football sign, cupola sign. 1ml of air can be detected
  • Perforation of the alimentary tract often leads to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Treatment includes early intervention for this patient presenting in the emergency department is adequate resuscitation with IV fluids, correction of electrolytes and antibiotics, urinary catheterization with or without GI compression.
  • Definitive treatment: emergency laparotomy

questions.text: A patient who had tibial fracture one month ago had his cast removed. We could see some ecchymosis on skin. A few days later he comes with pain on lifting his great toe, and decreased sensation in 1st web space. Posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis were felt, what will be the next step to perform?
questions.solution:
Above clinical scenario suggest: early phase of compartment syndrome

  • The classical clinical picture is that of severe pain out of proportion with clinical findings that worsens with time despite appropriate analgesia.
  • Pain on passive stretch - earliest sign
  • Absence of distal pulses-late sign
  • The patient often complains of numbness/paraesthesia in the distribution of nerves running within the compartment (non-myelinated type C sensory fibres are most sensitive to hypoxia).
  • Examination of the limb reveals a tense compartment with passive flexion and extension of muscles causing pain.
  • The presence of palpable pulses does not rule out compartment syndrome.
  • Next step if suspecting COMPARTMENT SYNDROME: to measure the compartment pressure using striker compartment measuring catheter
  • If the pressure is constantly above 30mm Hg - fasciotomy must be done
  • The usual site for fasciotomy is the calf (especially the anterior tibial compartment), but compartment syndrome may occasionally affect the thigh, arm and foot.
  • Liberal concomitant usage of calf with/without thigh fasciotomies following revascularisation of a prolonged ischaemic limb is advisable
